articles.title: Queensland Residents Urged to Move Amid Torrential Floods
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Thousands of people in north Queensland have been evacuated due to torrential flooding. The intense weather event has impacted the coastal Hinchinbrook Shire and the small town of Giru. Previous years' weather patterns in Australia indicate an increase in flood incidents, magnifying the risks for communities in the eastern regions.

articles.title: Zimbabwe's Economic Peril: Climate Change GDP Threat
articles.author: IANS
articles.summary: Zimbabwe's government's ambitious target to boost agricultural output to $12.5 billion by 2025 is under threat due to climate-induced challenges. The 2023/2024 El Nino-induced drought alone caused approximately $363 million in damage losses. World Bank co-author Easther Chigumira says a dual approach is essential to strengthen Zimbabwe's resilience to weather shocks and climate change.

articles.title: Eco-Logical Comment: Ocean levels rising at frightening rates
articles.author: Lily Butler
articles.summary: The sea levels have risen faster than any previous century in the last 3000 years. Since 1970, oceans have absorbed more than 93 per cent of excess heat. Most of the heat is concentrated around the Southern Hemisphere, melting the Antarctic ice shelves. Many people living along low elevation coastlines may lose their homes due to rising sea levels.

articles.title: World Bank warns Zimbabwe on climate-induced economic losses
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Climate change could erode up to 12 percent of Zimbabwe's GDP annually if the country does not implement robust measures to tackle the phenomenon. The World Bank urges Zimbabwe to bolster resilience against climate-related shocks focusing on agriculture as a critical pillar of the economy. The government's ambitious target to boost agricultural output to 12.5 billion U.S. dollars by 2025 is under threat.

articles.title: Rat populations spike in cities due to warming temperatures, study says
articles.author: Wtop
articles.summary: Washington D.C., San Francisco, Toronto, New York City, and Amsterdam have a higher number of rats due to increasing warming trends over the last 50 years. New York is following Chicago's example in trying to control rat population in its urban areas.

articles.title: Victorians urged to remain vigilant as 'baking' heat raises bushfire risk
articles.author: Daniel Miles
articles.summary: 700 firefighters and 63 firefighting planes battled blazes in the Grampians/Gariwerd National Park on Saturday. Shane Wells installed sprinklers and cleared the outskirts of his land in preparation for a possible fire. There is a forecast severe heatwave and high fire danger across most of Victoria.

articles.title: The Australian species spreading all over the world and exacerbating bushfires
articles.author: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
articles.summary: Eucalyptus tree plantations are contributing to bushfires from California to Portugal due to climate change. The trees are grown in plantations in nearly 100 countries and planted as city trees on every continent except Antarctica. Eucalypticus is an exotic tree introduced in the late 19th or early 20th century.

articles.title: Is Climate Change Fueling the Spread of Salmonella? Researchers Point Out Worrying Trend
articles.author: Jenn Jordan
articles.summary: Climate change is making it easier for Salmonella to spread, increasing the risk of foodborne illness, according to new research from the University of Surrey. Researchers analyzed 16 years of data from the UK Health Security Agency and compared it with more than a dozen weather factors from the Met Office. They found that temperatures above 50°F, higher humidity, and daylight hours lasting from 12-15 hours increased the risk.

articles.title: Melbourne median house price: What $900k will buy in other countries, from France to India
articles.author: Alesha Capone
articles.summary: Melbourne's median house price is $898,000. A renovated, 13-room chateau in Hains, France's northernmost region, is on the market for $768,616. A Neo-Gothic church converted to a house east of Clermont-Ferrand costs $635,130. A property in Montenegro is available for about €540,000 (AUD $903,295).

articles.title: Washington, DC is now the world's rat capital … and disgusting plague will get worse
articles.summary: A new study published in Science shows that rat populations rise in cities that experience rising temperatures due to climate change and urban heat islands, as well as in cities with rising urban areas, such as New York and London.    i.e. cities with increasing temperatures.

articles.title: Is There Anything Climate Change Can't Do? Now It's Rats
articles.author: Steve Milloy
articles.summary: There are more and more homeless people who don't properly dispose of food and other waste. City governments have stopped using rodenticides and rat control programs. Urban temperatures have not warmed because of emissions, but because of the urban heat island effect, which is due to the urban cycle.

articles.title: Why climate action plans fall short
articles.author: Eilia Jafar
articles.summary: In 2024, India faced 255 days of extreme weather, causing 3,238 deaths, 235,000 homes destroyed, and 3.2 million hectares of crops lost. In 2022, climate-related disasters in India caused $4.2 billion in economic losses. There is no dedicated legal framework for climate actions. Localised models integrating climate change adaptation (CCA) and disaster risk reduction (DRR) planning are lacking.

articles.title: January 2025 all set to be the warmest January month on record
articles.author: Abhishek Jha
articles.summary: Global average temperature in January 2025 is all set to be the highest for January month, according to ERA5 data from the Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) up to January 28. January 2025 will likely be the fourth January when warming relative to the pre-industrial average is at least 1.5°C, the long-term warming threshold set by the 2015 Paris Agreement to avoid catastrophic climate change.

articles.title: Dry spell to keep pressure on fire-ravaged state
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: Little rain is expected for Victoria in February, which could lead to a protracted bushfire season for the state already ravaged by blazes in its west. Authorities urge homeowners to prepare their properties and double-check evacuation plans. Heatwave conditions forecast from Sunday pose an imminent threat to emergency services crews battling fires in the Grampians region.

articles.title: Opinion Columnists  Larry Shubnell: Annapolis is long past due for a reimagined city government
articles.author: Larry Shubnell
articles.summary: The City Dock Action Committee (CDAC) was formed on March 20, 2019. CDAC is responsible for "reimagining" the City Dock. The first phase of the project has already been completed. The second phase will take place in the future. The city has been governed by committee since 1708.

articles.title: Unusually warm Jan stokes climate change concerns in city
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Ludhiana is experiencing a warm and sunny January. The weather should have been winter, but it felt more like peak of spring. There are concerns about climate change in the country.    The average January temperature is above the world's average.

articles.title: Models are changing
articles.summary: Fifty years ago scientists theorized what rising levels of carbon dioxide emissions might cause. Early models predicted temperatures would rise 0.2 to 0.5 degrees Celsius per decade. Other models predicted changes in weather conditions and ice melt. Today the world is slowly coming to realize that carbon emissions are not a threat.

articles.title: The Path of Hope: A Study on Climate Action for Faith Communities
articles.author: thekatynews
articles.summary: Thursdays, March 20 – April 10, 6 p.m. central, online. 15-minute videos walk viewers through four key climate policy issues that intersect with universal faith concerns for vulnerable and marginalized people. Discussion guide asks participants to think deeply about how their own local faith community's direct service programs intersect with climate impacts.

articles.title: More rats infesting cities amid warmer temperatures, scientists say
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: Washington has the highest rat infestation rate in the world, followed by San Francisco, Toronto, New York City and Amsterdam. New Orleans, Louisville and Tokyo have decreasing trends. Mardi Gras in Louisiana shows the biggest drop in rat reports. Scientists blame climate change, urbanization and other human actions for rat population growth.

articles.title: Blane Klemek Outdoors: Get ready for the Great Backyard Bird Count
articles.summary: The Great Backyard Bird Count is taking place from February 14 to 17. The event is organized by the National Audubon Society and the Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology. It's an easy-to-do and enjoyable way to contribute to wildlife research. Blane Klemek is a Minnesota wildlife manager.

articles.title: On Nature column: How wildlife copes with winter
articles.author: Sheryl Myers
articles.summary: Evolution has equipped wildlife with a variety of survival strategies. Humans adapt by building homes with indoor heat and wearing layers of insulating clothing. Mammals like skunks, bears, and groundhogs go into hibernation in cold weather. Studies show that humans gain an average of one to two pounds in the cold.

articles.title: Scientists warn a continent is splitting apart twice as fast as expected
articles.summary: Scientists warn that Africa is splitting apart faster than previously thought due to the East African Rift System. A 35-mile fissure in Ethiopia's desert, which appeared in 2005, widens at about half an inch per year. The rift represents a dynamic geological transformation with significant implications for Earth's geography and ecosystems.

articles.title: Asian Waterbird Census in Kollam records 11,525 birds from 81 species
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: Annual Asian Waterbird Census in Kollam district has counted 11,525 birds from 81 species, including 46 migratory species. This is a slight increase from the 2024 census, which recorded 11,470 birds from 83 species. The census observed a decline in wild duck numbers, likely due to low water levels in traditional wetland habitats. There was a higher-than-usual count of Asian Woolly Necked Stork, a local migrant listed as near threatened by the IUCN, for the first time.

articles.title: Kenora & Lake of the Woods Weather: Snowy & Chilly Weekend Ahead
articles.author: Netnewsledger Weather Desk
articles.summary: Snow is moving into Kenora and Lake of the Woods, with 5-7 cm expected. Wind chills of -31°C today will improve slightly, but freezing drizzle may make roads slippery. Winter Storm Warnings are in effect for Mine Centre and Seine River, along with Thunder Bay and points east along Lake Superior.

articles.title: Resilient Sarasota rebounds after back-to-back hurricanes
articles.author: Susan Glaser cleveland.com
articles.summary: Mable Ringling's roses will have to be replanted and St. Armands Circle needs to fill in a few vacant storefronts. Sarasota was hit by back-to-back hurricanes last fall, but it's faring well, all things considered.

articles.title: Coalition's aversion to solar power means higher bills
articles.author: Sydney Morning Herald
articles.summary: The majority of people are concerned about climate change, writes Anne O'Hara. She is concerned about the effects of climate change on people's well-being and the environment. She writes: "I'm concerned about it a lot.  I'm worried about it.

articles.title: BILL LEWIS: Easy Cash?
articles.author: Bill Lewis
articles.summary: Geographers and cartographers make maps. Persia switched to Iran, Siam to Thailand, Burma to Myanmar, Holland to the Netherlands, Ceylon to Sri Lanka, Swaziland to Eswatini, Rhodesia to Zimbabwe, and Czech Republic to Czechia are recent examples.

articles.title: Welcome to the Pyrocene
articles.author: Stephen Pyne
articles.summary: In recent years, fires have blasted through cities in Colorado, the southern Appalachians and the island of Maui, along with Canada, Australia, Portugal and Greece. Historian of fire says that humanity's fire practices have become so vast that we are creating the fire equivalent of an ice age.

articles.title: Stakeholders contribute to Dominica's Biennial Update Report and Biennial Transparency Report.
articles.author: Malaika
articles.summary: The Government of Dominica has collaborated with the Partnership Initiative for Sustainable Land Management (PISLM) to engage key stakeholders in a comprehensive discussion on January 21, 2024. This engagement aimed to gather insights for the country's Biennial Update Report (BUR1) and Biennial Transparency Report (BTR1). The BTR1 is critical as it represents one of the principal reporting mechanisms under the Enhanced Transparency Framework (ETF), a requirement for all nations that have ratified the Paris Agreement.

articles.title: New Bluesky Global Warming Feeds
articles.author: Mokurai
articles.summary: I have created a new collection of Bluesky Global Warming feeds bypassing Jonathan's broken feeds. Climate Change is the first one up. I will create all of the others today. I am accepting suggestions for other tags for these feeds and we can talk about other supported features.

articles.title: Nature Trail: Big climate changes can also happen naturally
articles.author: Jim Hurley
articles.summary: The last ice age wiped out most of the life from Ireland. The change in the Earth's orbit around the Sun caused the change and we returned to the warm stage that we are now living in. The warm stage started about 11,000 years ago and the cold stage before that lasted about 16,000 to 23,000. Fossils found in Ireland show that animals like the Giant Deer, Brown Bear, and Grey Wolf were early colonisers of Ireland together with the first human settlers who arrived about 8 thousand years ago.

articles.title: UW researcher helps describe how hummingbirds save energy
articles.author: Laramie Boomerang
articles.summary: Some hummingbirds make migrations of more than 5,590 miles a year. Their journeys are fueled by nectar, which is sipped from wildflowers and converted to fat. Climate and land-use change is making the distribution of wild flowers along their migratory routes more unpredictable. To buffer against this, hummingbirds use a process called torpor, a sort of overnight hibernation.

articles.title: Fact Check: Misleading UK CO₂ Figures Exposed
articles.author: DC Correspondent
articles.summary: A social media post claims that the UK produces under 1% of global CO2 emissions. It also claims that cow farts create 4% of UK emissions. Global warming is the rise in the average temperature of the Earth's surface caused by the release of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere.

articles.title: State Supreme Court upholds landmark ruling affirming overlooked constitutional right: 'We have been heard'
articles.author: Chloe Bryant
articles.summary: Montana Supreme Court upheld a ruling in favor of 16 youth plaintiffs. They argued Montana's backing of planet-warming fossil fuels violated their rights. The landmark decision will force Montana officials to assess the greenhouse gas emissions and climate impacts of all future fossil fuel permits. Rising global temperatures make weather more extreme and lead to more destructive disasters.

articles.title: Charting the path toward a climate-resilient Philippines
articles.author: The Philippine Star
articles.summary: The Philippines is among the most climate-vulnerable countries in the world, according to the UNFCCC. It is one of the most affected countries by climate change. It has a population of about 6.5 million people. It's the most populous country in the Philippines.

articles.title: While experts warn of the risk of wildfires, N.C. Forest Service struggles with 100+ vacancies
articles.author: Chaewon Chung
articles.summary: On Wednesday, a 250-acre wildfire broke out in McDowell County in Western North Carolina after a tree fell onto a powerline. This week's wildfire comes amid growing concerns about wildfire risk in the state due to climate change. North Carolina has experienced both intense hurricane seasons and unusually dry fall months in recent years. The state's Forest Service has more than 100 unfilled positions due to low salaries.

articles.title: Commentary: Climate extremes like snow threaten crop yields, grocery prices
articles.author: Bella Kubach
articles.summary: Pensacola saw 9 inches of snow last week, while many other Florida communities experienced record lows and freeze warnings. Florida's agricultural sector has contributed to the economy largely by bringing in millions of dollars for the state and providing thousands of jobs. However, the industry now faces threats with weather intensifying as a result of a warming atmosphere. According to a recent forecast, Florida farmers will fill 3 million fewer boxes of oranges this growing season.

articles.title: Hurghada Port closed due to severe weather
articles.author: MENA
articles.summary: Hurghada Port was closed on Friday 31/1/2025 due to bad weather conditions. The closure was prompted by high 3-4 meter waves and strong 23-26 mph winds, the Red Sea Ports Authority said. The port was closed due to high 3 to 4 metre waves and 23 to 26 mph winds.

articles.title: Coalition's aversion to solar power means higher bills
articles.summary: Jacqueline Maley and Anne O'Hara are right to be concerned about the cost of living and climate change. Many homes are now uninsurable due to an increase in the risk of property loss and damage driven by climate change, but the Coalition's plan to build several nuclear plants would leave less room in the grid for clean energy, including solar panels. Parnell Palme McGuinness reminds us that government is a monopoly.

articles.title: Taking science seriously is more important than ever as weather keeps changing
articles.summary: After one of the coldest Januarys in the past decade, the 'darkest months' of the year are behind us. The solstice on December 21 is the beginning of winter and the'shortest' day, but now the good Earth is spinning in our favor and daylight is increasing. In January each day features an additional two minutes of daylight and by mid-February that increases to around three minutes per day. Last July, for instance, was listed in many local areas as the second-warmest since weather watchers have been checking temperatures. According to the Associated Press, 2024 temperatures went past the warming limit of 1.5 degrees Celsius called for by the 2015 Paris climate

articles.title: With weak La Nina, January this year third warmest since 1901: IMD
articles.author: Anjali Marar
articles.summary: After record-breaking temperatures, January was the third warmest since 1901 in India. The weak phase of La Nina, the abnormal cooling of the sea waters along the equatorial Pacific Ocean, and southerly or easterly winds prevailed for several days. The country received 72 per cent below-normal rainfall last month. The most rainfall-deficient regions were central India (96 per cent) and northwest India (80 per cent). IMD forecast a warm February over most parts of the country.

articles.title: Letter: California wildfires were predictable
articles.author: Tulsa World
articles.summary: Dale McIntyre of Bartlesville says blaming global warming on humans' mistakes absolves them from their blunders. He thinks it's not fair to blame humans for their mistakes, but to blame an event on global warming is not fair either.

articles.title: Charting the path toward a climate-resilient Philippines
articles.author: Joanna Perfecto
articles.summary: The Philippines is at the top of the Global Climate Risk Index and the most vulnerable in the World Risk Index 2024. 74% of Filipinos face climate-related threats. Public satisfaction with the national administration on specific issues highlights disaster response as a top priority. The Philippines holds a distinctive role in leading significant climate initiatives.

articles.title: Rat populations in cities are booming as the planet warms up
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: Washington DC has the fastest growth in rats. Global warming is helping rats thrive in major cities around the world, especially in Washington DC and New York City, where rats are on the rise due to climate change.      .   i

articles.title: Connecticut man: Increased use of cultivated meat helps fight climate change
articles.summary: After the California wildfires, we need to get more serious about addressing global warming. Political leaders should support more public funding for cultivated-meat research. Cultivated meat is grown from livestock cells without slaughter. It will require a fraction of the greenhouse-gas emissions that raising and slaughtering livestock does.

articles.title: Eco-nomics: Knowing causes shows how to correct climate crisis
articles.summary: Attribution science allows us to better link the causes of warming to the climate crises that result. The past 10 years have been the hottest in recorded history, with increasing disasters: heat, wildfires, floods, drought, drought and sea level rise. Since 1980, the U.S. has sustained 403 climate disasters where damages exceeded $1.9 trillion.

articles.title: Revealed: What life on Earth will look like in 2100 - with entire cities plunged underwater and millions of people perishing in the heat
articles.author: WILIAM HUNTER
articles.summary: In the most optimistic scenario, the world achieves net-zero CO2 emissions by 2050. In the most pessimistic scenario, CO2 levels increase by 7.92°C above the pre-industrial average in the worst-case scenario. The number of people living in drylands will more than double from 2.3 billion to 5 billion in 2100.

articles.title: What we can expect on Earth as Sun's magnetic field prepares to flip
articles.summary: The Sun has a magnetic field and every 11 years its polarity changes direction. There is an increase in the number of eruptions from the Sun during this time. These eruptions can disrupt radio communications and GPS signals. The visible effects here on Earth are the aurora or "northern lights" we sometimes see.

articles.title: Economic experts emphasize the need for both short-term and long-term plans to reduce poverty in the country.
articles.author: TOLOnesws
articles.summary: The United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) has warned of a possible rise in food insecurity in Afghanistan. 32% of Afghanistan's population still requires urgent humanitarian assistance. The organization's humanitarian program for Afghanistan in 2024 required $1.44 billion, but only 56% of the budget has been secured so far.

articles.title: African children can thrive amid climate chaos
articles.author: Lynet Otieno
articles.summary: Kenya had to delay opening schools due to flooding. In South Sudan schools were closed for weeks due to high temperatures. Somalia experienced severe drought. At least 242 million children worldwide missed school due to extreme weather events in 2024. Children in low-income countries are disproportionately affected by climate change.

articles.title: Trough in easterlies over Southwest Bay of Bengal become less marked: Met
articles.author: Uniindia News Service
articles.summary: The trough in easterlies over Southwest Bay of Bengal has become less marked. Light to moderate rain is likely to occur at one or two places in South Coastal Andhra Pradesh and Rayalaseema during the next 24 hours. Lowest minimum temperature of 17.3 degrees celsius was recorded at Jangamaheswarapuram on the intervening night of Friday and Saturday.

articles.title: 70s for the Weekend, 80 next week!!
articles.author: Mike Modrick
articles.summary: Fires and drought are developing in central Florida. The Suncoast is now in Moderate Drought conditions. Several cold fronts bring rain to the southern half of the U.S., but most of them fizzle out before they reach Florida. Travel weather is quiet and warm for Florida.

articles.title: Malta, heat related deaths could triple
articles.author: Agenzia di Stampa Italpress
articles.summary: Malta could see 269 heat-related deaths per 100,000 by 2095 if temperatures rise by as much as 4°C. Mediterranean countries are particularly affected by rising temperatures. According to the UN, emissions cuts of 42% are needed by 2030 and 57% by 2035 for the world to be in with a chance of limiting temperature increases to 1.5°C by 2020.

articles.title: ‘Metabolic knife edge': Study offers insight into hummingbirds' hibernation-like rest
articles.author: Ashley Joannou
articles.summary: Migratory hummingbirds travel thousands of kilometres each year to breed in places like British Columbia and as far away as Mexico to avoid the winter cold. To make it there, hummingbirds sometimes enter a short-term hibernation of sorts, slowing their respiratory, heart and metabolic rates for several hours at a time.

articles.title: Inside a Dennis cottage for sale on Myrtle Lane, with access to Swan River. Photos.
articles.author: Jason Savio
articles.summary: 17 Myrtle Lane, Dennis Port is a new property for New Cape Real Estate/Zillow. It is located at 17 Merytle Lane and Dennis Port Road, both in Dennis Port, Cape Town, South Africa. It's for sale.

articles.title: Impact of climate change on world economy
articles.author: e NCA
articles.summary: The World Economic Forum's 2025 Global Risks Report paints a stark picture of the environmental, social, and geopolitical risks linked to extreme weather. South Africa has had its share of extreme weather, from devastating floods to scorching heatwaves. Dr Nomhle Ngwenya is a leading expert in the field.

articles.title: Food Crisis in Horn of Africa: 67.4 Million People Face Hunger
articles.author: IANS
articles.summary: There are 67.4 million people living in the IGAD member states, including Djibouti, Ethiopia, Kenya, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan and Uganda. There are also 29 million people displaced in the Horn of Africa, mainly in Sudan and the DRC.

articles.title: Soaring Food Prices Driven By Climate Change
articles.summary: India's food inflation rate has remained firm at 8.8 percent. Extreme weather conditions have burdened food prices during the past two years. Vegetables and pulses contributed to 32.3 percent of the overall inflation as of FY25. When excluding staple food items such as tomatoes, onions, and potatoes from the equation, the average food inflation is 4.3%.

articles.title: Australian researchers create a new detailed map of Antarctica's ice-free land
articles.summary: Australian researchers have created a detailed map of Antarctica's ice-free land that they say will help protect the continent's biodiversity. The team, led by the University of New South Wales (UNSW) Sydney, unveiled the new high-resolution map on Wednesday. They also created a hierarchical classification system of the ecosystems in Antarctica.

articles.title: Heatwave raises fire danger across Victoria
articles.author: Angus Delaney
articles.summary: A heatwave is starting on Sunday and is expected to worsen the current bushfires in the Grampians and the Little Desert national parks. A lack of significant rain for February means the bushfire season is likely to be longer than usual. Western and central parts of Victoria will be most at risk of new fires.

articles.title: CLIMATE HUGS: Wayne Moorman a strong voice on water supply issues
articles.author: Nanci Langford
articles.summary: This month's Communities Protecting our Coast climate hug goes to Wayne Moorman, a retired civil engineer who has lived in Parksville for 20 years. He is concerned about the health and stability of the Englishman River and Arrowsmith Lake, both of which are critical to the city's water supply. His first involvement was in the Grieg Greenway Society, formed by Linda Harbo. The society was concerned about a proposed development on Grieg Road, which would have been built on a flood plain. It was successful and the rezoning was not approved by council in 2023. It also contributed to the recent Nature Trust purchase of 13 acres of land at 130 Shelly Rd

articles.title: Government plans 700 km sea wall from Banten to East Java
articles.author: Putu Indah S
articles.summary: President Prabowo Subianto ordered his ranks to review the construction of a giant sea wall from Jakarta to Cirebon as part of a National Strategic Program (PSN) for 2025. The project will protect rice fields on the north coast of Java Island from rising sea levels.

articles.title: The Pioneering Attribution Science Links Climate Change To Weather Disasters
articles.summary: In the future, attribution studies could play a growing role in legal disputes. The main questions attribution studies seek to answer are: did the warmer climate make a flood, heatwave, fire or storm more likely, and did it increase its ferocity? Several groups have developed methods that have been independently validated by other researchers. The most active and influential group is World Weather Attribution.

articles.title: City of Cape Canaveral to Host Huge Sea Oats Volunteer Planting Event on Feb. 15
articles.author: Since
articles.summary: The City of Cape Canaveral will hold one of its largest volunteer planting events on Saturday, February 15, from 8:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m., with plans to plant 19,776 more sea oats across nearly two miles of beach-facing dunes. Since 2005, volunteers and City Staff have planted 196,838 sea oats. Sea oats are a perennial grass native to the southeast of the US. The City will plant over 220,000 sea oats beachside by 2036.

articles.title: Africa's longest coastline that stretches a staggering 2,071 miles long
articles.author: Emily Wright
articles.summary: Somalia's northern and eastern coastlines are separated by the tip of the Horn, Cape Guardafui. The northern coast faces the Gulf of Aden, while the eastern coast is bordered by Kenya, Ethiopia and Djibouti to the west. The coastline offers Somalia access to maritime routes that connect Africa to the Arabian Peninsula and the Indian subcontinent. It is rich in biodiversity, with 63 species of corals and several species of dolphin and turtle. The terrorist group Al Shabaab continues to carry out frequent attacks in Somalia.

articles.title: Scottish dairy herd numbers concerns
articles.author: Kelly Henaughen
articles.summary: Scottish dairy herd numbers have declined by 23% over the last decade. The total number of dairy cows decreased by 257 in last year, but the average herd size increased to 236. Ayrshire experienced the most significant decrease with a net loss of 15 herds, followed by Dumfriesshire with a loss of five herds.

articles.title: Study reveals 40.85 per cent of Similipal Biosphere Reserve highly susceptible to forest fires
articles.author: Hemant Kumar Rout
articles.summary: 40.85% of Similipal Biosphere Reserve is highly susceptible to forest fires. 2021 is the peak year for fire incidents, with 94.72% of the fires occurring during March and April. The buffer zone experienced the highest number of incidents with significant anthropogenic activity and topographic features.

articles.title: Not Ducky: Hunting pressure, change in DNA impacting North American mallards
articles.author: Steve Knight
articles.summary: Another duck season has ended in the Central Flyway and hunters in Texas were left wondering where the ducks are. Kevin Kraai, Texas Parks and Wildlife Department waterfowl program leader, said a mid-winter duck count over the playa lakes showed mallards did make it to Texas. The birds' migration through the state continues to trend farther to the west, although by only 20-40 miles. There are changes in duck activity most likely caused by hunting pressure.

articles.title: How Anambra state can navigate Nigeria's food crisis
articles.summary: Nigeria is facing a food crisis. 33 million Nigerians are at risk of food insecurity in 2025. Food prices have risen by 95% in the South East region. Anambra State has a potential to reverse the current food crisis in the region. The state has a total land area of 4,844 square kilometres. It is almost 100% arable.

articles.title: Sea surface warming four times faster now than in 1980s
articles.author: Issac James Manayath
articles.summary: Oceans absorb about 90% of the heat trapped in the Earth's atmosphere by greenhouse gases. Sea surface temperatures have risen more sharply in recent years compared to the 1980s. Global ocean temperatures hit record highs for 450 consecutive days in 2023 and 2024. El Nino Southern Oscillation triggered the exceptionally high GMSSTs of 2023-2024. The energy imbalance between Earth and Sun has doubled since 2010.

articles.title: HIV, transgender care, climate change and other federal websites go dark
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: by | | Climate Change is a website dedicated to the study of climate change. For more information, visit: http://www.climatalkin.org/news/environment/environmental-change/chimatockexchange.html.

articles.title: India 7th most prone to climate change
articles.author: Tribune News Service
articles.summary: The survey described India as the seventh most vulnerable country to climate change. It pointed out India was prone to extreme weather patterns and phenomenon like sea-level rise, biodiversity loss and growing water scarcity. Estimates suggest climate change could reduce India's GDP by 3 to 10 per cent annually.

articles.title: BREAKING PALISADES FIRE BOMBSHELL: Former Director Of HUD Says The Los Angeles Fires...
articles.author: Freedomsphoenix Readerfour
articles.summary: Alex Jones spoke with financial expert Catherine Austin Fitts about the manmade California fires and their true purpose on Thursday's show. Catherine Austin fitts is an expert on financial matters. She is also a financial expert on the California fires. She explains their origin and purpose.

articles.title: See which cities are experiencing a surge in rats due to climate change
articles.author: Andrew Wulfeck
articles.summary: There are significant increases in rat populations in 11 out of 16 U.S. cities, including Washington, D.C., New York and Amsterdam, while Tokyo and New Orleans experienced declines. There are about 3 million rats in New York City, most of them of the Norway species. The Big Apple is in the midst of extensive rodent control efforts.

articles.title: ‘Pakistan Seed Security Prototype' launched to build resilience among farming communities
articles.author: Zubair Qureshi
articles.summary: Agro-pastoral communities in Pakistan continue to confront the effects of climate crisis, economic deterioration and high prices for food and agricultural supplies. International Rescue Committee and Unilever collaborated to develop 'Pakistan Seed Security Prototype' which is aimed at building resilience of the farming communities. The report was launched at 'Pakistan's Humanitarian Future Event 2025'.

articles.title: Leaders in the Pacific raise alarm over ‘direct impact' of Trump's climate retreat and aid freeze
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Samoa's PM says US withdrawal from Paris climate agreement is disappointing and puts the survival of Pacific countries at greater risk. Leaders and environmental advocates in the Pacific have expressed alarm over Donald Trump's decision to withdraw from the Paris climate accord.  .

articles.title: Could the UK actually get colder with global warming?
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (Amoc) that circulates warm water from the tropics to the North Atlantic could weaken in response to climate change. Global warming is making the water in the north Atlantic less salty. This is expected to slow the circulation and bring less saltwater northwards from the Tropics.

articles.title: Insuring the uninsurable: Climate risk and role of insurance industry
articles.summary: The last 10 years from 2014 to 2024 are the 10 warmest years on record. 2024 was probably the first calendar year with a global mean temperature more than 1.5°C above the 1850-1900 average. Global losses exceeded $ 300 billion for the ninth time in a row and were significantly higher than the long-term average for previous decades. Less than half of the economic losses were insured. The gap between insured and uninsured losses is often called the 'protection gap' in developing countries.

articles.title: Climate Change: Is It The Greatest Crisis Or A Global Deception
articles.author: Dianne Plummer
articles.summary: According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, humans are responsible for almost all global warming observed over the past two centuries. The Earth is now approximately 1.2°C hotter than pre-industrial levels according to NASA. UNEP's Emissions Gap Report shows that a 42% global emissions reduction by 2030 could still limit warming to 1.5°C, requiring an annual cut of 22 billion tons.

articles.title: Rats worldwide are enjoying the perks of climate change
articles.author: Yahoo Daily News
articles.summary: Climate change is contributing to a global rise in urban rat infestations, according to a new Science Advances study. As temperatures increase, rats are better at living in urban areas.      .   for confidential support call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90, visit a local Samaritans branch or click here.

articles.title: Ocean warming accelerated fourfold in 40 years, intensifying climate crisis
articles.author: Madhyamam
articles.summary: Ocean temperatures have been rising at an alarming rate. The pace of warming has quadrupled over the past four decades. This rapid increase is contributing to intensified climate change, affecting sea levels, extreme weather patterns, and food security worldwide. Scientists warn that without urgent action, the situation will get worse.

articles.title: Nature Trail: Big climate changes can also happen naturally
articles.author: Irish Independent
articles.summary: Extreme weather events are the result of global warming, climate change, and extreme weather events, according to the IPCC. The IPCC reports that extreme weather can be caused by climate change or global warming. It is estimated that the current global warming trend is due to climate change.

articles.title: Major East Coast city's disgusting increase in number of rats featured in new study... and ...
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: Washington, DC has experienced the largest increase in rat population due to global warming. The study analyzed public complaints and inspection data from 16 cities worldwide. It is the first time that researchers have directly connected rat population growth to the global warming phenomenon. The report has been published in Science Advances.

articles.title: 'Metabolic knife edge': Study offers insight into hummingbirds' hibernation-like rest
articles.author: North Shore News
articles.summary: Migratory hummingbirds travel thousands of kilometres each year to breed in British Columbia and sometimes as far away as Mexico to avoid the winter cold. To make it there, hummingbirds sometimes enter a short-term hibernation of sorts, slowing their metabolic rate.

articles.title: Could the UK actually get colder with global warming?
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: Some scientists fear the risk of a collapse to warm Atlantic currents has not been taken seriously, as it is not being taken seriously enough.   for example, by the European Commission and the United Nations. For more information, go to: http://www.esa.org/news/environmental-sciences/topics/climate-change.

articles.title: Connecticut man: Increased use of cultivated meat helps fight climate change
articles.author: Metrowest Daily News
articles.summary: After the California wildfires, we need to get more serious about addressing global warming. Political leaders should support more public funding for cultivated-meat research, among other things, to combat the risk of disasters such as this one, as well as addressing climate change.

articles.title: Harvesting uncertainty: Climate change and India's agriculture
articles.author: Deccan Herald
articles.summary: Climate change has a direct impact on agriculture. Rising temperatures affect crop growth cycles, leading to reduced yields and changes in rainfall patterns often cause droughts or floods. Studies by the studies by the World Resources Institute show that climate change is a threat to agriculture.

articles.title: Why the Arctic matters in the 21st century
articles.author: Beijing News
articles.summary: The Arctic is one of the coldest and least populated regions on Earth. It has become a key focus of U.S. policy in recent years. The land north of the Arctic Circle has long been inhabited by people from the Arctic.

articles.title: Life cycles of some insects adapt well to a changing climate: Others, not so much
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Some biologists speculate that animals will get smaller with global warming to reduce heat stress. This may be true for warm-blooded animals, but not for exotherms like heat-exotherms.   Â. Â   y   Y

articles.author: The Scotsman

articles.title: Cornwall mayor, Akwesasne chief frustrated by increasing tolls on U.S.-Canada bridge
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: There will be increased tolls on the Seaway International Bridge near Cornwall, Ont., and in the border-spanning Mohawk Nation at Akwesasne, Canada, because of the construction work. The Mohawk people are unhappy about it.

articles.title: Climate action network for concerted efforts to tackle water shortage in Sindh
articles.author: Urdu Point
articles.summary: Sindh province experiences a 52% decline in rainfall compared to the average. There are serious concerns about water security, agriculture and the livelihoods of millions. SCAN has sounded the alarm. The situation in Sindh is critical, according to SCAN.

articles.title: Study shows increase in Peregrine Falcons in Oman
articles.author: Oman Observer
articles.summary: There is an increase in the number of Peregrine Falcons on an island, according to a field study conducted by the Environment Conservation Office at the Environment Authority, which confirmed it from the island's population data.      .   in the study.

articles.title: A look at generative AI's environmental impact in figures
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: Generative artificial intelligence's ecological footprint is one of the top questions up for discussion at a global summit in Paris on February 10-11. There are growing concerns about the technology's impact on the environment and environment is a topic of discussion at the summit.

articles.title: Economic Survey: Adaptation strategy critical for India given vulnerability to climate change
articles.author: Business Line
articles.summary: India is the'seventh' most vulnerable country to climate change. The Economic Survey emphasised on climate adaptation strategies on an 'urgent footing' as emissions impose huge costs on already resource-constrained countries. India needs to undertake climate adaptation on an urgent footing as this has a direct impact on lives and livelihoods.

articles.title: Warnings and health advice as high-risk hot spell settles in
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Health services warn of the dangers of heat-related illness on the vulnerable amid soaring temperatures across south-east Australia as the heatwave continues.      .   in South-East Australia  in the last few days has been very hot.

articles.title: Climate Change: Is It The Greatest Crisis Or A Global Deception
articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: Explore the debate on climate change causes: human activities vs. natural variability. Discover the latest data, scientific consensus, and impacts of global warming. Find out the scientific consensus on the causes of climate change and the impacts of human activity on the environment.

articles.title: Why climate action plans fall short
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: The climate crisis is no longer a distant threat but an urgent reality. Despite global efforts to address the crisis, climate action plans often fall short of expectations. From policy gaps to insufficient community involvement, systemic challenges hinder the progress. To effectively counteract climate change, we must.

articles.title: Connecting the dots between climate action and the community
articles.author: Monterey Herald
articles.summary: Monterey County administrators are going to release the first draft of the Community Climate Action and Adaptation Plan now that a three-year community engagement period has ended. Residents raised concerns about affordability and how reducing the county's greenhouse gas emissions will affect Monterey County.

articles.title: 'Doomsday Clock' nears midnight
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Earth is moving closer to destruction, a science-oriented advocacy group says. It advanced its famous "Doomsday Clock" to 89 seconds till midnight, the closest it has ever been to the date of the end of the world, it says. The group is concerned about climate change.

articles.title: Lack of climate finance may prompt developing countries to rework their climate targets
articles.author: New Delhi
articles.summary: The lack of financial support from developed countries to mitigate climate change in the Global South may prompt developing countries to'rework' their climate targets, India's Chief Economic Advisor V Anantha Nageswaran has said. According to the UNFCCC, developed countries are required to provide finance, technology and capacity building support to developing and low-income economies to help them cope with a warming world. Developed nations are pushing developing nations to meet the Paris Agreement goals.

articles.title: Common Sense Has Been Sent Packing
articles.summary: Water pipes broke in the Upper Ohio River Valley, iguanas fell out of trees in Florida, and New Orleans had a blizzard. Global warming is a myth, according to Mark Eddy. He questions the political affiliation of the current occupant of the White House.

articles.title: Damage to CWASA pipeline disrupts water supply in half of Ctg
articles.author: Daily Sun
articles.summary: Loss and Damage: Beyond Climate Change Mitigation, Adaptation and Resilience is a book about climate change mitigation, adaptation and resilience. It is published by Oxford University Press. For more information, visit: www.oliverpub.com/london.

articles.title: Income inequality in Bangladesh worsens
articles.author: Daily Sun
articles.summary: Asian Economy is under Threat from Climate Change, according to the World Bank. The world economy is under threat from climate change, the report claims. The World Bank is concerned about the impact of climate change on the Asian economy.   Â
